Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Response of Lake Superior to anomalously high ice cover during the winter of 2013-2014
Award.AbstractNarration:
The winter of 2013-2014 was a remarkably harsh, cold winter throughout much of the upper midwest, resulting in record low average temperatures and high snowfall amounts. One of the interesting and potentially important consequences of this anomalously cold winter is the high amounts of ice formed on the US/Canadian Laurentian Great Lakes. While all of the lakes experienced anomalously high levels of ice, Lake Superior was a true standout. In most years, Lake Superior does not freeze over completely. In very cold years, Lake Superior might be frozen over completely for a few days in the late winter, but this past year Lake Superior spent nearly all of February and March completely frozen over. In early May, the lake was still over 50% ice-covered. This situation presents a unique opportunity to better understand the implications of the anomalous ice conditions for the lake for subsequent summer and fall. Given the long term trend towards lower ice cover on Lake Superior (and rivers and lakes around the world), an opportunity to study such extreme conditions and their consequences may not occur again in the foreseeable future.

Intellectual Merit: A growing body of research acknowledges the strong connection in deep, temperate lakes between winter ice cover and lake thermal conditions for most of the rest of the year. A short extension of an on-going deployment of three open-lake moorings in Lake Superior through the summer of 2014 following several years when ice coverage levels have been relatively low represents an opportunity to significantly extend the dynamic range of our understanding of the role that ice plays.

Broader Impacts: As part of the observational work, the principal investigator will make the additional ship time associated with this project available to the wider scientific community and share the collected data in order to have a wider, interdisciplinary perspective on the impacts of the record-breaking ice levels. Several community-building exercises will be developed to use the high-ice year as a gauge of the current level of understanding and two graduate students would receive training in taking and interpreting field observations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The winter of 2013-2014 was characterized by extreme cold temperatures across the upper Midwest, due to the so-called ‘polar vortex’. Due to this extreme cold, ice cover on the US/Canada Great Lakes broke records for extent and duration of ice- ice was observed on Lake Superior as late as early June. Our lab had equipment deployed in Lake Superior which we used to measure properties of the ice and of the water below the ice. We were able to analyze measurements made under the ice, and extended the array of instrumentation through the following summer, in order to study the impact of the high winter ice coverage on following seasons. As most of what we know about ice on the Great Lakes has come from remote sensing (satellite) data, having instruments in the water under the ice during a heavy ice year is an important step forward.

 

Primary results of this work include:

  • Formation of ice on the Great Lakes is very sensitive to even small changes in air temperature. On Lake Superior, the difference between a heavy ice year and a year with virtually no open-lake ice may be due to a difference in seasonally averaged winter air temperature of just 2-4°F. Given that climate change predictions for the Great Lakes region forecast air temperature changes of this magnitude over the coming decades, we can expect to see more years with little or no ice, and fewer years with robust ice cover.
  • Onset of stratification (when the lake starts to form a warm layer on top) was later this year than we have ever observed, with some eastern portions of the lake not stratifying until early to mid August. This typically occurs in late June to early July.
  • Ice drifts on the Great Lakes, and is strongly coupled to the wind. The ice moves at about 3% of the wind speed, and moves in a direction somewhat to the right of the wind direction.
  • From above, the ice may look like a giant, flat surface, but there are actually large ‘keels’ below the ice- nearly half of the total mass of ice on the lake in a heavy ice year may be contained in these keels, and they get up to 30 feet thick.
  • The water column is periodically simultaneously inundated by small ice crystals across much of the lake.

 

These results are an important part of our understanding of the Great Lakes system as a whole. Ice plays a significant role in heat exchange with the atmosphere and with the light environment in lakes, both of which are important to the ecosystems of lakes. Data collected on this grant will also benefit numerical modeling studies of ice-covered lakes, since so little data like these exist.
